text: This is a game.

It’s called the Ultimatum Game and there’s
a big pot of money.
But you have to split that pot with me.

You need to decide how you want to split the
pot – think 80/20 or 50/50 – and suggest
that to me.
If I agree, we both get our share.

If I reject the offer, neither of us get any
money.
What do you do?

This game has been used a lot in tests of
fairness.

And things like your brain chemistry or electrical
stimulation of certain brain regions affect

how people decide to split the pot, and if
others accept their offer.

In one study, participants were given a pill
of amino acids or a placebo, and then they
played the Ultimatum Game.

Those who had the amino acid pill rejected
unfair offers in 80% of cases, and those who

took the placebo rejected unfair offers 65%
of the time.

The amino acid pill didn’t include tryptophan,
the amino acid necessary to synthesise serotonin,

a chemical that plays a role in regulating
emotion during social decision-making.

So reduced serotonin resulted in more resentment
towards the offer, making the responders less
likely to accept it.

Another study bent the rules of the Ultimatum
Game.

When the participants first split the pot,
they offered 10-25% of the value to their
partner.

But if their partner had the power to change
the way they split the pot, their initial
offer jumped to 40-50%.
Then the Ultimatum Game became electrifying.

Some participants received electrical stimulation
that increased activity in a brain area thought
to control fairness.

And, on average, those people increased their
original offer by 33%.

Others received electrical stimulation that
decreased activity in the same area, and they
decreased their original offer by 22%.

And a recent study found that participants
offered their partner more money from the

pot when they were given Tolcopone, a drug
that prolongs the effects of dopamine, compared
to a placebo.

It’s kind of mind-blowing that our sense
of fairness and inequality can be manipulated
by drugs and electrical stimulation.
But…
can you really win the Ultimatum Game?

Have you won if you get 20% or 40% of the
pot, because it’s more money than you had
before?

Or do you have to get more money than the
other person to truly win?

Based on rational self-interest, responders
should accept any offer above zero and proposers
should offer the smallest amount possible.

But studies have shown almost half the players
will reject offers of 30% or less, meaning

you’re kind of paying to stop the other
player from getting more money than you.
You’re willing to pay for equality.

So… how would you split the pot of money
with me?

Let me know what you think and how you would
split the money in the comments.

And I’ll let you if I would accept your
offer.
